qas.question: What must organisms have a measurable level of to be seen as a subspecies?
Who proposed subspecies be defined by the seventy-five percent rule?
What year did Dean Amadon make his proposal?
The 75% rule states how much of a population must lie outside the range of other populations for a defining set of characters?
Many scholars argue what should be replaced with a ninety or ninety-five percent rule?

context: This effectively means that populations of organisms must have reached a certain measurable level of <a0_0>difference<a0_0/> to be recognised as subspecies. <a1_0>Dean Amadon<a1_0/> proposed in <a2_0>1949<a2_0/> that subspecies would be defined according to the seventy-five percent rule which means that 75% of a population must lie outside <a3_0>99%<a3_0/> of the range of other populations for a given defining morphological character or a set of characters. <a4_0>The seventy-five percent rule<a4_0/> still has defenders but other scholars argue that it should be replaced with ninety or ninety-five percent rule.
